questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and dry cough for 2 days. His symptoms began after he helped his father clean the basement. He is allergic to shellfish. Respirations are 26/min. Physical examination shows diffuse end-expiratory wheezing and decreased inspiratory-to-expiratory ratio. This patient's symptoms are most likely being caused by inflammation of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Asthma typically has no effect on the pleural cavity. Inflammation in the pleural cavity can be due to an empyema, which typically presents with fever, pleuritic chest pain, and dyspnea, which is inconsistent with the patient's presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Because alveoli are so thin-walled and lack smooth muscle, they do not contribute significantly to the bronchospasm that causes most of the symptoms in asthma. Inflammation at the alveolus is common in hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which usually results from exposure to birds or moldy plant matter. Though this patient has a recent mold exposure, his presentation is not typical of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which usually presents with flu-like symptoms, dyspnea without wheezing, and rales on auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

While inflammation of the respiratory bronchioles can occur in asthma, it does not contribute significantly to the onset of symptoms. Respiratory bronchioles don't have concentric smooth muscle, as there are gaps in their walls where alveoli branch out. Because of this, respiratory bronchioles are not the most likely location of bronchoconstriction and airway obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

The distal trachea has cartilaginous rings to keep the airway patent, and as a result, does not contribute significantly to the bronchospasm that causes most of the symptoms of asthma. Inflammation of the trachea is common in croup, a disease that typically presents with a barking cough following a URI-like prodrome.

E) CORRECT:

The symptoms of asthma are primarily caused by inflammation of the terminal bronchioles. Terminal bronchioles are lined with smooth muscle but lack the cartilage found in larger airways. When an allergen triggers a hypersensitivity reaction there is bronchial submucosal edema and smooth muscle contraction and the airways collapse, as they don't have the support of cartilage. This collapse leads to the symptoms of asthma.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of atopy, wheezing and prolonged expiratory phase after exposure to allergens (mold spores) are most likely signs of asthma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with recurrent pneumonia comes to the physician for a follow-up examination one week after hospitalization for pneumonia. He feels well but still has a productive cough. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F) and respirations are 20/min. Cardiopulmonary examination shows coarse crackles at the right lung base. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen of the right lower lung parenchyma shows proliferation of clustered, cuboidal, foamy-appearing cells. These cells are responsible for which of the following functions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lecithin refers to a class of fatty substances used by type II pneumocytes to produce lung surfactant. Lecithin is stored as lamellar bodies in the cytoplasm, giving the cells their foamy appearance. When released, these amphipathic molecules decrease the surface tension in alveoli and increase lung compliance, thus facilitating breathing.

B) INCORRECT:

Alveolar macrophages are a major source of cytokine release in the lower lung. Macrophages also take on a foamy appearance through the accumulation of digested fats that the cells scavenge. However, alveolar macrophages are large and pleomorphic with large eccentric nuclei, unlike the proliferating clusters in this patient's biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Toxin degradation in the lower lung is chiefly conducted by club cells. These cuboidal, non-ciliated cells are present in the terminal bronchioles of lungs. However, club cells are not the progenitors of types I and II pneumocytes and do not form clusters of cuboidal, foamy-appearing cells after lung injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Gas diffusion in the respiratory portion of the lungs occurs through the extremely thin type I pneumocytes. This thinness is established by localizing all organelles close to the nucleus, leaving a two-membrane thick surface area for gas diffusion. These cells are unable to replicate and would not appear as proliferating cells in the biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Mucus secretion in the lungs is carried out by goblet cells. These cells contain mucin granules that stain positive for PAS and line the respiratory tract until the terminal bronchioles. Goblet cells, however, are tall, simple columnar cells, unlike the proliferating clusters found in this patient's biopsy.
questions.hint: Clustered, proliferating cuboidal cells from an affected area of the lung are consistent with type II pneumocytes.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after coughing up 2 cups of bright red blood. A CT angiogram of the chest shows active extravasation from the right bronchial artery. A coil embolization is planned to stop the bleeding. During this procedure, a catheter is first inserted into the right femoral artery. Which of the following represents the most likely subsequent route of the catheter to the source of the bleeding?

choices.text: Thoracic aorta → right common carotid artery → right bronchial artery
Thoracic aorta → right posterior intercostal artery → right bronchial artery
Thoracic aorta → right superior epigastric artery → right bronchial artery
Thoracic aorta → right pulmonary artery → right bronchial artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The thoracic aorta gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, which in turn gives rise to the right common carotid artery and right subclavian artery. The common carotid artery supplies the head and neck region. A few individuals have an anatomic variation in which the right bronchial artery arises from the right subclavian artery but the right bronchial artery does not originate from the right common carotid artery or its branches.
Image Description:

Ventral view

The left subclavian artery arises directly from the arch of aorta. The right subclavian artery arises from the brachiocephalic artery. At the outer border of the first rib, the subclavian arteries continue as the axillary arteries. The main branches of the subclavian artery (from proximal to distal) are:
- Internal thoracic artery (internal mammary artery)
- Vertebral artery
- Thyrocervical trunk
- Costocervical trunk

B) CORRECT:

The right bronchial artery has several possible origins, including directly from the thoracic aorta, from the left superior bronchial artery, and, most commonly, from the 3rd right posterior intercostal artery (sometimes referred to as the intercostobronchial trunk). The 3rd to 11th posterior intercostal arteries branch directly from the thoracic aorta. Therefore, in order to embolize the right bronchial artery from the right femoral artery, the catheter would need to travel to the thoracic aorta and then to a posterior intercostal artery before arriving in the right bronchial artery. On the left side, there are typically two bronchial arteries (left superior bronchial artery, left inferior bronchial artery) both of which originate directly from the thoracic aorta.

While the pulmonary arteries supply almost 99% of the blood flow to the lungs, the blood they carry is deoxygenated and participates in gas exchange rather than supplying nourishment. The bronchial arteries supply only 1–2% of the blood flow to the lungs but provide oxygenated blood to the lungs' supporting structures. Bleeding from the bronchial arteries is responsible for approx. 90% of cases of hemoptysis.

C) INCORRECT:

The superior epigastric artery supplies blood to the anterior abdominal wall and diaphragm and originates from the internal thoracic artery. The internal thoracic artery is a branch of the subclavian artery, which in turn arises from the thoracic aorta. However, the superior epigastric artery does not supply the chest wall or pulmonary structures, and neither the left nor right bronchial arteries originate from a superior epigastric artery.

D) INCORRECT:

The pulmonary arteries are branches of the pulmonary trunk, which originates from the right ventricle (not from the thoracic aorta). They carry deoxygenated blood to the lungs for gas exchange and oxygenation. The bronchial arteries, on the other hand, carry oxygenated blood to supply pulmonary structures and do not originate from the pulmonary arteries.
Image Description:

Blue: structures that carry deoxygenated blood
Red: structures that carry oxygenated blood
questions.hint: The branch of the thoracic aorta that typically gives rise to the bronchial artery lies posterior to the thoracic duct, azygos vein, and esophagus.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after his daughter found him unresponsive. Despite appropriate care, the patient dies. At autopsy, examination of the lungs shows enlargement of the airspaces in the respiratory bronchioles and alveoli. Which of the following types of cells constitute the largest proportion of alveolar surface area lost in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonciliated cuboidal cells (club cells) line the distal terminal bronchioles and the respiratory bronchioles of the respiratory system. These cells secrete glycosaminoglycans and lysozymes as well as degrade toxins to maintain the integrity of the respiratory epithelium. Club cells, however, are not present in pulmonary acini, and damaging these cells would not cause the panacinar emphysema seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Type I pneumocytes are squamous cells that comprise > 95% of the alveolar surface and are necessary for optimal gas exchange. This patient had alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, in which uninhibited protease activity destroys the lung parenchymal tissue that consists predominantly of type I pneumocytes. This causes deformation of entire acini, and ultimately alveolar space enlargement and decreased total surface area for gas exchange.
Image Description:

The alveolar walls contain three cell types: type 1 pneumocytes, type 2 pneumocytes, and alveolar macrophages. Type 1 pneumocytes are thin, flat cells that form the alveolar structure and make up 95% of its surface. Type 2 pneumocytes are far smaller in size but more numerous (thus accounting for about 60% of alveolar cells but taking up only 5% of the surface space) and produce the surfactant, which covers the entire alveolar lumen to reduce surface tension. The alveoli are separated from each other by the interalveolar septum with elastic fibres and capillaries; interalveolar pores connect adjacent alveoli.

C) INCORRECT:

Type II pneumocytes are cuboidal cells that comprise ∼ 5% of the total alveolar surface area. Because they serve as precursors to type I pneumocytes, destruction of these cells would reduce the lung's capacity to regenerate damaged tissue. In addition, type II pneumocytes are responsible for the production and secretion of surfactant, which reduces alveolar surface tension and prevents the collapse of pulmonary acini. This patient has evidence of panacinar emphysema, a condition that instead results in airspace enlargement.

D) INCORRECT:

Ciliated cuboidal cells line the terminal bronchioles of the respiratory system. Their cilia allow for removal of mucus and debris from the lower airways. Conditions such as Kartagener syndrome cause cilia dysfunction leading to impaired mucociliary clearance and bronchiectasis. Damage to these cells, however, would not cause the panacinar emphysema seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Ciliated columnar cells help form the lining of the airway's conducting zone from the bronchi to the beginning of the terminal bronchioles. They are important for mucociliary clearance. Dysfunction of these cells is seen in Kartagener syndrome. Damage of these cells, however, would not cause the panacinar emphysema seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of bronchial tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Layers of the bronchial wall are visible. The innermost layer is formed by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (marked with green outline) containing goblet cells (yellow overlay) and intercalated between epitheliocytes. Beneath the epithelium is a fibromuscular layer (smooth muscle tissue marked by green overlay) with hyaline cartilage (black dashed outline) and seromucous glands (black dotted outline).
questions.hint: Patients with alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency lack protection against elastase-mediated destruction of the major cell type in the respiratory zone of the lungs. This leads to panacinar emphysema.

questions.text: An investigator is conducting a study to document the histological changes in the respiratory tree of a chronic smoker. He obtains multiple biopsy samples from the respiratory system of a previously healthy 28-year-old man. Histopathological examination of one sample shows simple cuboidal cells with a surrounding layer of smooth muscle. Chondrocytes and goblet cells are absent. This specimen was most likely obtained from which of the following parts of the respiratory system?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Respiratory bronchioles are part of the gas-exchanging respiratory zone of the lung. These segments have simple cuboidal epithelium without cartilage or goblet cells, as described in this patient's case. However, smooth muscle is sparse in respiratory bronchioles and exists only between adjacent pulmonary alveoli. A concentric smooth muscle layer like the one in this histologic specimen would not be present. In addition, respiratory bronchioles are frequently indented with alveoli, but there are no alveoli in the sample.

B) INCORRECT:

Tertiary bronchi are downstream from the main stem bronchi in the intrapulmonary conducting system of the lungs and are composed largely of the same tissue layers. These layers include plated cartilage, a smooth muscle layer, and pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. The simple cuboid epithelium seen in this histologic sample would not be present in a tertiary bronchus.

C) CORRECT:

The terminal bronchioles represent the final segment of the intrapulmonary conducting system prior to the respiratory portion of the lungs. As the intrapulmonary conducting system divides into smaller and smaller branches, the cartilaginous layer characteristic of the bronchi disappears and the smooth muscle layer thickens relative to the airway diameter in order to regulate airway resistance. The smallest branches of the conducting system are devoid of goblet cells and are composed of a simple cuboidal epithelium with a few ciliated cells and club cells, as described in this patient's case.
Image Description:

Overview of the different types of respiratory epithelium and components of the airway walls

The height of the epithelium decreases steadily from the trachea to the alveolar sacs and the distribution and prevalence of cell types and extracellular components changes throughout the airways.

(Note: The length and width of the bars indicate the approximate relative distribution and prevalence of the structures shown but do not represent absolute numbers or metric data.)

D) INCORRECT:

Conducting bronchioles are the penultimate branch of the intrapulmonary conducting system and have a thickened smooth muscle layer without cartilage or goblet cells, as described in this patient's case. However, these segments are primarily lined by simple ciliated columnar epithelial cells, not the simple cuboidal epithelium found in the histologic sample.

E) INCORRECT:

Alveolar sacs contain a small number of cuboidal type II pneumocytes but are predominantly composed of type I pneumocytes, which are squamous cells, not the cuboidal epithelium described here. Furthermore, the smooth muscle seen in this histologic specimen would not be expected in alveolar sacs.

F) INCORRECT:

The main stem bronchi, located proximally in the intrapulmonary conducting system, have plated cartilaginous layers and thin smooth muscle layers relative to their diameters. Although smooth muscle is also present in this sample, cartilage is not. Additionally, main stem bronchi are lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, not the simple cuboidal epithelium seen here. Furthermore, goblet cells would be expected in a main stem bronchus sample.
questions.hint: This part of the respiratory tree is embryologically derived from endodermal tubules during the pseudoglandular stage of lung development. It offers the least resistance to airflow.

questions.text: An investigator studying new drug delivery systems administers an aerosol containing 6.7-μm sized particles to a healthy subject via a nonrebreather mask. These particles are found to deposit on the surface of a pseudostratified epithelium. Which of the following is the most likely route of clearance of the particulate matter in this subject?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Particles larger than 10 μm are usually trapped by the nasal vibrissae. With a smaller particle size, similar to the one used in this experiment, the aerosols will most likely bypass the vibrissae and penetrate deeper within the respiratory tree.

B) INCORRECT:

Entrapment of larger particles (> 10 μm) within the nasopharyngeal cavity may result in clearance by either manual extraction or swallowing. This experiment uses smaller sized (6.7 μm) particles. These particles will, therefore, most likely bypass the defenses in the nasopharyngeal cavity, travel further down in the respiratory tree, and be cleared via another mechanism.

C) CORRECT:

Particles that range from 3–10 μm in size are most likely to deposit in the trachea and/or the bronchi, which are lined by a pseudostratified epithelium. These particles are then trapped in mucus secreted by goblet cells and subsequently pushed upward toward the nasopharyngeal cavity by the action of the ciliated epithelium of the respiratory tract, i.e., the mucociliary escalator.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of bronchial tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Layers of the bronchial wall are visible. The innermost layer is formed by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (marked with green outline) containing goblet cells (yellow overlay) and intercalated between epitheliocytes. Beneath the epithelium is a fibromuscular layer (smooth muscle tissue marked by green overlay) with hyaline cartilage (black dashed outline) and seromucous glands (black dotted outline).

D) INCORRECT:

Very small particles that range in size from 1–3 μm can penetrate deep within the respiratory tree and into the alveoli. These particles are then phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages. This experiment, however, uses larger sized (6.7 μm) particles that deposit on pseudostratified epithelium. Therefore, these particles will most likely have been trapped and cleared by mechanisms further upstream from the alveoli, which are lined by simple cuboidal and squamous epithelium.

E) INCORRECT:

Nano-sized particles that are < 0.1 μm (100 nm) can diffuse into the pulmonary capillaries. Although most inhalational drugs can be directly taken up by the pulmonary capillaries, the particles in this experiment are much larger (6.7 μm) and will, therefore, be deposited further upstream from the alveolar capillary network. Furthermore, the alveoli are lined by simple cuboidal and squamous epithelium, not pseudostratified epithelium.
questions.hint: Goblet cells are involved in this clearance process.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of worsening painful swallowing, hoarseness, and bilateral otalgia. He has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss during this period. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Laryngoscopic examination shows an abnormal mass located on the right true vocal cord. Immunohistochemistry of the mass shows expression of HPV-16 DNA. This neoplasm most likely derived from which of the following types of epithelial tissue?

choices.text: Simple squamous epithelium with type I and type II cells
Stratified squamous epithelium with submucosal glands
Simple cuboidal epithelium with club cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Simple squamous epithelium with type I and type II cells lines the alveolar sacs. Type I pneumocytes are large flat squamous cells that facilitate gas exchange, while type 2 pneumocytes are more cuboidal and produce surfactant. HPV is not associated with any malignancies of the alveolar epithelium.
Image Description:

The alveolar walls contain three cell types: type 1 pneumocytes, type 2 pneumocytes, and alveolar macrophages. Type 1 pneumocytes are thin, flat cells that form the alveolar structure and make up 95% of its surface. Type 2 pneumocytes are far smaller in size but more numerous (thus accounting for about 60% of alveolar cells but taking up only 5% of the surface space) and produce the surfactant, which covers the entire alveolar lumen to reduce surface tension. The alveoli are separated from each other by the interalveolar septum with elastic fibres and capillaries; interalveolar pores connect adjacent alveoli.

B) CORRECT:

The true vocal cords have stratified squamous epithelium and a submucosal layer with mucous and serous glands that help lubricate the cords. The stratified squamous epithelium of the vocal cords consists of 5–25 layers of non-keratinized cells. The basal layer of the epithelium contains cells that are nucleated and appear more columnar or cuboidal. The cells become increasingly polygonal and flattened toward the surface. The HPV virus exhibits tropism for squamous epithelium. HPV-16 and HPV-18 are high-risk subtypes of HPV, which are associated with a greater risk of dysplasia and squamous cell cancer, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Simple ciliated columnar epithelium lines the bronchioles as far as the terminal bronchioles. The true vocal cords have a different type of epithelium and HPV does not exhibit tropism towards columnar cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (Ladewig trichrome stain; 200x)

A bronchiole (with a prominent air-filled lumen) is visible at the center of the image. Its wall features ciliated simple columnar epithelium and circular bundles of smooth muscle. Note that, unlike in a bronchus, there is no cartilage and glands. An arterial vessel is visible left of the bronchiole. Its entire lumen is filled with erythrocytes. The bronchiole and arterial vessel are surrounded by numerous air-filled alveoli.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium lines the mainstem bronchi and trachea, not the vocal cords. Moreover, HPV does not exhibit tropism towards columnar cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tracheal tissue (H&E stain; 300x magnification)

Tissue layers from top to bottom and from inside to outside:
– Pseudostratified respiratory epithelium (green overlay) with occasional goblet cells (examples indicated by yellow overlays) and the basophilic nuclei of the basal cells that are arranged in a palisade-like pattern
– Lamina propria with lots of collagen and elastic fibers, containing numerous seromucous tracheal glands (examples indicated by black arrows; excretory duct outlined in black) that are surrounded by smooth muscle (white dashed outline)
– Incisions of several blood vessels
The characteristic tracheal cartilage rings cannot be seen in this image.

No pathologic features are noted.

E) INCORRECT:

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium lines the trachea and main-stem bronchi. Depending on which part of the bronchus or trachea is examined on histopathology, cartilage may or may not be seen. The larynx does not have a pseudostratified columnar lining, and HPV does not exhibit tropism towards the columnar epithelium.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tracheal biopsy sample (Ladewig trichrome stain; 50x magnification)

Tissue layers (from top to bottom and the outside in):

- Mediastinal connective tissue (white)
- Plate of hyaline cartilage (purple; hatched green overlay)
- Perichondrium (dark purple; black overlay)
- Smooth muscle (red; yellow overlay)
- Lamina propria with elastic fibers (red; red overlay)
- Respiratory epithelium (pink; green overlay)
- Tracheal lumen (white; hatched red overlay)

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

F) INCORRECT:

Simple cuboidal epithelium lines the respiratory bronchioles, which are part of the gas-exchanging respiratory zone of the lung. Club cells (Clara cells) are non-ciliated and interspersed with ciliated cuboidal epithelium. The true vocal cords do not have cuboidal epithelium and HPV is not associated with any malignancies of the respiratory bronchioles.
Image Description:

Overview of the different types of respiratory epithelium and components of the airway walls

The height of the epithelium decreases steadily from the trachea to the alveolar sacs and the distribution and prevalence of cell types and extracellular components changes throughout the airways.

(Note: The length and width of the bars indicate the approximate relative distribution and prevalence of the structures shown but do not represent absolute numbers or metric data.)
questions.hint: The presence of dysphagia, hoarseness, otalgia, and weight loss in an adult man without traditional risk factors (smoking, alcohol use) and an abnormal laryngeal mass is consistent with laryngeal carcinoma. HPV is associated with 20% of all laryngeal cancers in North America and Europe.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being stabbed in the chest with a screwdriver. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 90/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a 5-cm deep stab wound at the upper border of the 8th rib in the left midaxillary line. Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intercostal nerves, arteries, and veins are located along the inferior margin of their respective rib. This patient's injury immediately above her 8th rib is, therefore, unlikely to have damaged any intercostal neurovascular structure.

B) INCORRECT:

The liver is located on the right side of the body and would not reach the left midaxillary line in a healthy individual. In addition, the liver's anterior margin can be located as high as the 10th rib, but it is generally found at approximately L1, not the 8th rib.

C) INCORRECT:

The spleen is located immediately behind the 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs along the midaxillary line, and it descends slightly with inspiration. Although the injury is close to this patient's spleen, a puncture wound above the 8th rib is more likely to injure a different organ.

D) CORRECT:

The left lower lung lobe crosses the 8th rib along the midaxillary line, extending an additional 3–5 cm with inspiration. This patient's injury immediately above her 8th rib is most likely to puncture her lower lung lobe, causing her symptoms (hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea) that are consistent with pneumothorax.
Image Description:

ICS: intercostal space

E) INCORRECT:

The left ventricle forms the apex of the heart, which is located in the 5th intercostal space along the sternal line, not the 7th intercostal space along the midaxillary line. This patient's injury is, therefore, too low and posterior to have injured her heart.

F) INCORRECT:

The kidneys are located in the retroperitoneal area of the abdomen. They are partially covered by the 11th and 12th ribs with a limited projection along the midaxillary line, but they are not covered by the 8th rib.
questions.hint: The mamillae roughly project onto the 6th rib in the midclavicular line.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the clearance of respiratory particles in healthy nonsmokers. An aerosol containing radio-labeled particles that are small enough to reach the alveoli is administered to the subjects via nonrebreather mask. A gamma scanner is then used to evaluate the rate of particle clearance from the lungs. The primary mechanism of particle clearance most likely involves which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Goblet cells secrete mucus, which traps larger particles (3–9 μm), usually in the trachea and/or bronchi, after which the trapped particles are propelled toward the nasopharyngeal cavity by ciliary movement. The aerosol particles in this experiment are small enough to reach the alveoli, so they are not likely to be cleared by mucociliary clearance.

B) INCORRECT:

Ciliated columnar epithelial cells line the trachea and bronchi and clear particles 3–9 μm in size. Such particles are usually trapped in the trachea and/or bronchi, after which they are propelled towards the nasopharyngeal cavity by ciliary movement. The aerosol particles used in this experiment are small enough to reach the alveoli, so they are not likely to be cleared by mucociliary clearance.

C) INCORRECT:

Club cells are nonciliated, secretory, cuboidal cells located in the terminal bronchioles and respiratory bronchioles. Their main functions include degrading toxins and maintaining the integrity of the respiratory epithelium by secreting specific immunomodulatory proteins, glycoproteins, and lipids. They are not directly involved in removing particles from the alveoli.

D) INCORRECT:

Type I pneumocytes are thin squamous cells that line the alveoli, comprising 95% of the total alveolar area. Together with the endothelial cells of the capillaries and the basement membrane between the two cells, they form the blood-air barrier, facilitating gas diffusion across the alveolar wall. However, they are not directly involved in removing particles from the alveoli.

E) CORRECT:

Inhaled particles within the respiratory tree are cleared by different means depending on their size. Small particles (< 3 μm) penetrate deep within the respiratory tree, into the alveoli, where they are cleared by the alveolar macrophages. Particles between 3–10 μm deposit into the trachea and/or bronchi and are cleared through expulsion by the mucociliary escalator. Particles ≥ 10 μm are trapped within the nasal cavity and cleared by the nasal vibrissae. Given that the aerosol particles in this experiment are small enough to reach the alveoli, these particles are most likely to be cleared by alveolar macrophages.

F) INCORRECT:

Type II pneumocytes are cuboidal cells that line the alveoli, comprising 5% of the total alveolar area. They contain lamellar bodies, which secrete surfactant, a compound that reduces alveolar surface tension and thereby prevents the alveoli from collapsing. Type II pneumocytes can also proliferate to replace type I and type II pneumocytes during lung damage. They do not play a role in removing inhaled particles from the alveoli.

G) INCORRECT:

Neutrophils are part of the innate immune system. Their functions include antigen recognition, phagocytosis, and production of bactericides. Neutrophils are key players in mediating the exacerbation of lung inflammation and injury but are not directly involved in removing particles from the airways and lungs.
questions.hint: These cells mediate the removal of inhaled particles from the alveoli.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 6-month history of cough and dyspnea. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Analysis of the sputum sample from bronchoalveolar lavage shows abnormal amounts of an isoform of elastase that is normally inhibited by tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs). The cell responsible for secreting this elastase is most likely also responsible for which of the following functions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lactoferrin is produced by neutrophils, which also produce elastase. However, neutrophil elastase is degraded by alpha-1 antitrypsin, not by TIMP. Macrophages, which are the cells responsible for secreting the specific isoform of elastase described here, are activated by lactoferrin but do not produce any lactoferrin themselves.

B) INCORRECT:

Type II pneumocytes produce surfactant. They are not involved in the production of metalloproteinases.

C) INCORRECT:

Club cells are primarily responsible for the degradation of toxins in the lower lungs. They do not produce metalloproteinases.

D) INCORRECT:

Gas diffusion in the respiratory portion of the lungs occurs through the extremely thin type I pneumocytes. Type I pneumocytes do not produce metalloproteinases.

E) CORRECT:

Alveolar macrophages secrete both metalloproteinases (e.g., macrophage elastase) and phagocytose foreign materials. Neutrophils also are capable of these two functions, but the type of elastase secreted by neutrophils is degraded by alpha-1 antitrypsin, not TIMPs. Degradation of alveolar interstitial tissue by elastases plays a role in the pathogenesis of emphysema, which is most commonly caused by smoking and would present with worsening cough and dyspnea, as seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Goblet cells line the respiratory tract until the terminal bronchioles and function to secrete mucus. They do not produce metalloproteinases.
questions.hint: Metalloproteinases are a subtype of elastase enzyme that degrade interstitial connective tissue.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a coworker for an injury sustained at work. He works in construction and accidentally shot himself in the chest with a nail gun. Physical examination shows a bleeding wound in the left hemithorax at the level of the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?

choices.text: Left middle lobe of the lung
Left upper lobe of the lung
Left lower lobe of the lung

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unlike the right lung, the left lung has no middle lobe. The left lung has a sub-segment, the lingula of the left lung, which is thought to be a remnant of the middle lobe.

B) INCORRECT:

While the right atrium of the heart is located between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space, it is mainly located posterior to the sternum. It is not located in the left hemithorax, where this patient's injury occurred.

C) INCORRECT:

The superior vena cava is located in the superior mediastinum slightly lateral to the right sternal border between the 1st and 3rd intercostal space. It is not located in the left hemithorax, where this patient's injury occurred.

D) INCORRECT:

The inferior vena cava is located below the 4th intercostal space just to the right of the sternum. It is not located in the left hemithorax, where this patient's injury occurred.

E) INCORRECT:

The left atrium of the heart is located between the 2nd and 3rd intercostal space slightly lateral to the left sternal border, which is superior and medial to the point of injury in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

The left upper lobe of the lung is anterior to the left lower lobe with boundaries extending from above the first rib to about the 6th intercostal space along the midclavicular line. Thus, a penetrating wound in the 4th intercostal space of the anterior left chest will most likely involve the left upper lobe.
Image Description:

ICS: intercostal space

G) INCORRECT:

The left lower lobe of the lung primarily occupies the posterior and lower hemithorax and approaches the anterior hemithorax below the 4th intercostal space. However, this patient's wound is in the 4th intercostal space of the anterior left chest.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child examination. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following structures would continue to increase in number in this child?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The formation of new skeletal myocytes (also known as myofibers) from the mesodermal layer ceases at around 16 weeks' gestation. From this point onward, the skeletal myocytes grow in length and width via hypertrophy but the number of cells remains the same.

B) INCORRECT:

The formation of new nephrons, which originate from the mesodermal layer, ceases around 36 weeks' gestation. From this point onward, renal function continues to increase via nephron hypertrophy, which is induced by hemodynamic stress.

C) INCORRECT:

The number of brown adipocytes decreases over time after birth. Brown adipocytes, which develop from the mesoderm, are particularly important for heat production in newborns. Upon reaching adulthood, they are usually concentrated only around the vertebra, clavicle, mediastinum, and large arteries.

D) CORRECT:

There are 20–70 million alveoli at birth and approx. 300 million alveoli in a healthy adult. Between 36 weeks' gestation and 8 years of age, alveoli continue to increase in number (but not in size) through the formation of secondary alveolar septa. This process, also known as the alveolar stage, marks the final stage of lung development. Prior to this stage, the lungs and airways undergo four stages of development: the embryonic stage (weeks 4–7), pseudoglandular stage (weeks 5–17), canalicular stage (weeks 16–25), and saccular stage, in which primary alveolar septa form (from 26 weeks' gestation to birth).

E) INCORRECT:

At birth, a normal ovary contains 1–2 million primary oocytes, which have begun meiosis I. Throughout life, the ovaries are incapable of producing new oocytes and there is a continuous decline in the total number of primary oocytes each month. Upon reaching puberty, only approx. 25% of primary oocytes remain (∼ 300,000), and they resume meiosis I to form secondary oocytes. This division, however, only produces one functional secondary oocyte, the other product being a polar body. Thus, the total number of oocytes in female individuals decreases continuously after birth. In contrast, the number of primary and secondary spermatocytes, which originate from spermatogonia, increase following puberty in males.
Image Description:

Primordial germ cells migrate to the gonads in utero and become oogonia (♀) or spermatogonia (♂).

Oogenesis: Within the ovaries, oogonia undergo mitosis in utero to form primary oocytes. After birth, primary oocytes undergo meiosis, which is arrested in prophase I until puberty. Meiosis I resumes shortly before ovulation and the resulting secondary oocyte remains arrested in metaphase II. Meiosis II is only completed shortly after fertilization to form an ootid. Each oogonium results in the formation of one ootid and three degenerating polar bodies during oogenesis. In the absence of fertilization, the secondary oocyte degenerates.

Spermatogenesis: Within the testes, spermatogonia remain inactive until puberty. At puberty, spermatogonia undergo mitosis to form primary spermatocytes, which then undergo meiotic division to form four spermatids within a time span of 64 days. Spermatids develop into spermatozoa under the influence of testosterone (spermiogenesis).
questions.hint: The precursor for this structure begins to develop approx. during the fourth week of gestation and originates from endodermal tissue.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effects of influenza virus on human lung tissue. Biopsy specimens of lung parenchyma are obtained from patients recovering from influenza pneumonia and healthy control subjects. Compared to the lung tissue from the healthy control subjects, the lung tissue from the affected patients is most likely to show which of the following findings on histopathologic examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In response to inflammation and damage, club cells proliferate and differentiate into ciliated cells to regenerate the epithelial lining of the bronchioles. Thus, they are increased, not decreased, in the lung tissue of patients recovering from influenza pneumonia.

B) INCORRECT:

In response to lung inflammation and damage, macrophages disseminate from the bloodstream to the lungs and are increased in the lung tissue of patients recovering from influenza pneumonia. Alveolar macrophages phagocytose cellular debris to facilitate tissue healing.

C) INCORRECT:

In response to inflammation and damage, fibroblasts proliferate to facilitate tissue healing. Thus, they are increased, not decreased, in the lung tissue of patients recovering from influenza pneumonia.

D) CORRECT:

Alveoli consist of type I pneumocytes, which are thin, squamous cells that form the majority of the alveolar surface, and type II pneumocytes, which are cuboidal cells that form clusters in alveolar tissue. Type II pneumocytes proliferate in response to lung damage (e.g., from influenza infection) and can differentiate into type I pneumocytes, which are unable to replicate. Type II pneumocytes also secrete surfactant, which decreases surface tension and prevents alveolar collapse.

E) INCORRECT:

The lung parenchyma consists primarily of alveolar squamous epithelial cells (type I pneumocytes). Influenza pneumonia, which directly involves the lung parenchyma, causes cell apoptosis and results in a decrease, not increase, in alveolar squamous epithelial cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Goblet cells produce mucus to protect the upper airway. These cells are found in the upper portion of the conducting zone of the lung (i.e., the trachea and bronchi) and thus would not be seen on histopathologic examination of lung parenchymal tissue.
questions.hint: The influenza virus exhibits tropism for a cell type that is capable of regenerating alveoli after lung injury.
